text: Now, I know what you’re thinking: “What the heck do I need a five- spindle for? I barely sell enough shakes to justify my single spindle.” Right? Wrong. (BEAT)

Mr. Paulsen, are you familiar with the notion of the chicken and the egg? I mention it because I believe it’s applicable here: Do you not need a Multimixer because you're not selling enough milk shakes? Or are you not selling enough milk shakes because you don’t have a Multimixer? I firmly believe it’s the latter. You see, your customers, they know that if they order a shake from your establishment, it’s going to be a terrific wait. They’ve ordered one before, and by golly they’re not gonna make that mistake again. But if you had, say, a Prince Castle- brand five-spindle Multimixer with patented direct-drive electric motor, you could greatly increase your ability to produce delicious, frosty milk shakes fast. And before long, mark my words, dollars to donuts, you'd be selling more of those suckers than you can shake a stick at. Increase supply, demand will follow. Chicken and the egg. You follow my logic? Of course you do. You’re a bright, forward- thinking fella who knows a good idea when he hears it. (BEAT)
So whaddaya say? ON THE OWNER-- pondering thoughtfully.
Nah. (BEAT)

Thanks anyway.  EXT. ED’S DRIVE-IN - PARKING LOT - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc lugs the heavy Mulitmixer back to his car. He lifts into the trunk, wincing from his bad back. INT. KROC’S CAR —- MOMENTS LATER Kroc sits in his car checking his APPOINTMENT BOOK. His n sales call: DEE DEE’S DRIVE-IN - 1 P.M. He checks his watch. It’s 12:05. He turns on the car, pul into a customer spot in front of Ed’s Drive-In. He looks at the MENU BOARD, taking in the vast, seemingly random assortment of items: BBQ beef sandwiches, hot tama peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, chili dogs, etc. INT. KROC’S CAR - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc sits in his car, waiting for his food. He looks at h watch. It’s 12:50. He lets out a heaving, exasperated sig KROC’S POV, the view out his windshield: a rowdy TEEN-HAN SCENE. Rock-and-roll blasting from cars; female CARHOPS o rollerskates dodging grabby male patrons; leather-jackete cigarette-smoking hoodlums smacking each other around. Kroc is the oldest customer by a mile--and seemingly the one with anywhere to be. He HONKS his horn, summoning his CARHOP. She comes skating over holding a tray of Cokes.
Miss, how much longer?
Should be any minute.
You said that 20 minutes ago.

I’m sorry, we're real-- She JUMPS-SQUEALS, startled. The tray of Cokes goes flyin into the car, SPILLING ALL OVER KROC’S LAP. Several glass and plates fall on the ground, SHATTERING. Carhop Girl spins around, sees a GUY behind her cracking He just pinched her butt.
Dennis! (re: Kroc, soaked) Look what you made me do!

Sorry, gramps. Dennis scampers off toward his pack of laughing friends. carhop goes chasing after him, mad but not actually mad. ON KROC-- looking down at the pool of bubbly brown liquid his lap. He HONKS, leans out the window.
Could I get some napkins? No one hears him.
ANGLE ON the pants drying on the shower’s curtain rod.

It’s going great. CUT TO: the NEXT ROOM. Kroc sitting on the bed, on the ph RAY KROC (CONT’D) Lot of good leads today. Real strong leads. Through the phone, a tiny passive-aggressive sigh. RAY KROC (CONT’D) (prickly) What?
Nothing. That's wonderful.
There’s tremendous interest.
I’m sure there is.
You don’t believe me?
Of course, Ray. Why wouldn’t I?

Kroc sits on the edge of the bed, roiling from the call. takes off his shirt, undressing for bed. His bare torso b numerous surgery scars: heart, gall bladder, etc. He reaches over to the night stand, grabs a fifth of Cana Club. Unscrews the cap.
Kroc, in pajamas, stands before a PORTABLE PHONOGRAPH. He drops the needle on a record.
Kroc lies in bed in the darkened room, eyes closed. A soothing baritone fills the air--

Nothing in the world can take the place of persistence. Talent will not; nothing is more common than unsuccessful men with talent. Genius will not; unrewarded genius is almost a proverb. ANGLE ON record sleeve next to the phonograph: “THE POWER THE POSITIVE” BY DR. CLARENCE FLOYD NELSON
Education will not; the world is full of educated derelicts. Persistence and determination alone are omnipotent. QUICK CUTS to other snippets of the record:
So I grabbed that brush, and I shined up those boots so bright, Pastor Walker could see his reflection in them! Later--
The lesson there being, it’s not what you do but how you do it. Any job worth doing is worth doing well.  Later-- Later-- Later-- Later-- Later--
As I like to say, it’s not the size of the dog in the fight, it’s the size of the fight in the dog.
Misfortune is just a stepping stone to fortune.
And I said to myself, “Clarence, you’ve got to muddle through this!”
How a man handles adversity is the true measure of a man.
Heck, anyone can paddle in a sunshower!
The kitchen of another drive-in, Kroc pitching to the OWN The scene is virtually identical to the previous day’s.
Increase supply, demand will follow. Chicken and the egg. You follow my logic? Of course you do. You're a bright, forward-thinking fella who knows a good idea when he hears it. (BEAT)
So whaddaya say?

Kroc lugs the sample Multimixer back to his car.  INT. KROC’S CAR - SHORT TIME LATER Kroc is pulled up to a customer spot in front of Joe’s Dr In. The scene before him is very much like the one at Ed’ Drive-In, a riot of teenage rowdiness. He looks at his watch. It’s 12:45. He HONKS, shouting out no one in particular:
Could someone tell me when my... He trails off as a female CARHOP approaches with a tray. hooks the tray onto his car door.
Enjoy. She heads off. He lifts the cover off his plate, primed t dig in. His face falls at the sight of the hamburger bene He leans out the window, honks.
I ordered the barbecued beef! He’s howling into the void. EXT. MERRIMAN’S DRIVE-IN - LATER Another drive-in. Kroc with the OWNER.
Mr. Merriman, are you familiar with the notion of the chicken and the--

No, thank you. The Owner disappears into the restaurant. Kroc, shut down lugs the Multimixer over to his nearby car, heaves it int the trunk. He takes a swig from his FLASK. EXT. MERRIMAN’S DRIVE-IN - MOMENTS LATER Kroc at a pay phone, dialing a long-distance number.
Prince Castle, how may I help you?
Hi, June.  INT. PRINCE CASTLE SALES —- CONTINUOUS A modest office in a Chicago high-rise. At the reception is secretary JUNE MARTINO. (Intercut as necessary.)
Ray. How’s it going down there?
Fine, swell, lot of interest.

That’s terrific. Hold on, I'1l fetch your messages. She grabs a pile of messages off the desk. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) Let’s see: Gene Rafferty from United Aluminum, says he needs to reschedule Friday... Ed Nance calling again about the refund... a lady from March of Dimes about a donation... oh, and we got an order. Six.
Six?
Some drive-in out in California.
One place? That’s impossible.
I’ve got the slip right here.
You must've misunderstood. Give me the number, I'll straighten it out. EXT. MERRIMAN’S DRIVE-IN - SHORT TIME LATER-— Kroc pours a few nickels into the pay phone, dials a numb off his wrist.
Hello?
Good afternoon. May I please speak to the owner?
Which one?
I'm sorry?
Dick or Mac?
Um, whomever’s available. The guy puts the phone down, heads off. Through the recei Kroc hears the sounds of an insanely busy--and efficient- kitchen. “Order up!”... “I need six fries!"”... “Patties
This is Dick.
Hello Dick, this is Ray Kroc from Prince Castle Sales. I’m phoning because someone there placed an order with us for some Multimixers.
Yes, yes, that was me. How soon can you get ‘em out here?
Well, that’s actually why I was calling. I believe there may have been a miscommunication between-- In the background, someone SHOUTS SOMETHING to Dick.
Freezer! Top shelf, left side! (back to Kroc) Sorry.
My secretary’s under the impression you wanted six.
You know what? I think that’s a mistake.
That’s what I figured. What kind of drive-in would be making 30 shakes at a--
Better make it eight. ON KROC-- flabbergasted. Another background SHOUT. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) What’s that, Al? There’s a brand- new box in the storeroom! (to Kroc) Look, now isn’t the best time.
I’m sorry, I’m still a bit--
You know where to send ‘em, right? San Bernardino, California. Corner of 14th and E.
To anyone in particular?

Just the store is fine. McDonald's. Another BACKGROUND SHOUT distracts Dick. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) I gotta go. Just get those mixers out here ASAP, okay? Thanks! Click. Kroc stares at the receiver. What the hell was tha EXT. MERRIMAN’S DRIVE-IN - MOMENTS LATER Kroc stands over a U.S. ROAD MAP on the hood of his car. unfolds it, opening the map westward. (Note: This part of map is not well-worn like the Midwest; it’s virgin territ for Kroc.) Kroc’s eyes drift westward to California. They land on a small town 60 miles east of Los Angeles: San Bernardino. Kroc looks at the whole country. He notices something. A directly connecting St. Louis to San Bernardino. Route 66 ON KROC-- staring at Route 66. A single, unbroken line running from where he is now to that mysterious city out Southern California.  10.

Kroc driving west on Route 66. Cars, the open road, a limitless horizon. The sky, the country, the whole world seems to open up. His heart swells with possibility. The vastness excites his brain. This must be how Lewis & Clar felt. And then...

Kroc arrives in San Bernardino. A drab, dusty little town the edge of the desert. Hardly the pot of gold at the end the rainbow he was expecting. He continues along Route 66 heading toward the center of town.

Kroc driving. He sees the line before he sees the restaur A long line, hundreds of people, snaking toward a HAMBURG STAND in the distance. ON KROC-- taking in the strange sight of people out of th cars, queued up in a line leading toward a self-service window. It’s a distinctly FAMILY CROWD, lots of parents w their children. Not a teenage delinquent in sight. He parks, gets out. Unsure what to do, he gets in the lin He looks off at the restaurant, checks his watch. It’s 1:
Don’t worry. It moves fast. ANGLE ON the WOMAN in front of him. No sooner does she sa this than the line moves. Kroc shuffles forward 10 feet.
Kroc in line, significantly further along. He looks at hi watch. It’s 1:19.
Kroc at the front of the line. He checks his watch. 1:23.
Welcome to McDonald’s, may I take your order?  11. Kroc looks up, sees a CASHIER looking at him with a frien smile. Like all the other cashiers, he’s male and wholeso as apple pie.

Um, yes... He looks at the MENU BOARD. It has just FOUR ITEMS: burge fries, shakes, and Coca-Cola. A radical departure from th typical sprawling drive-in menu. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Hamburger, fries, and a Coca-Cola.
45 cents, please. Kroc hands him two quarters.
And five cents is your change. Kroc barely has time to put the nickel away when--
Here you are. The cashier hands him a paper sack. Kroc looks at it with confusion.
What’s this?
Your food.
I just ordered.
(shrugs, smiles) And now it’s here. Kroc peers into the bag. Lo and behold, inside is a burge fries, and a Coca-Cola. He sees it’s all wrapped in PAPER
("Where are the”--) Silverware? Plates?
You just eat it straight out of the wrapper. Then throw it all out.  12. ON KROC-- bewildered. He takes the bag, unsure what to do
So now I bring it back to my car?

Most folks do. Or you could eat it in the park, at home... anywhere you like. Kroc nods. This is all so strange to him. He turns, heads toward his car. On the way, he spots an EMPTY BENCH. He impulsively takes a seat. Kroc reaches into the bag in his lap. He takes out the hamburger, noting the paper packaging. He unwraps the bur looking at it, sniffing it. It looks and smells wonderful As he’s about to take a bite, out the corner of his eye h notices in a nearby car... a GORGEOUS BLONDE. KROC’S POV: The blonde, biting into a hamburger. As she chews, a look of ecstasy comes over her face. She closes eyes, her head tipping back a bit, borderline orgasmic. ON KROC-- staring at the blonde.
May we? Kroc is shaken out of his reverie by a FAMILY OF FOUR loo to sit on the bench. He slides over, making room.

Thank you. Kroc’s attention shifts from the blonde to the family. He discretely watches as the mother passes out burgers to he two young kids. The kids bite into them, “mmm”-ing audibl ON KROC-- observing this family of four, wholesome as can devouring their delicious McDonald's hamburgers. Kroc looks at the burger in his own hand, takes a bite. A chews, his eyes roll back in his head.
How is everything? Kroc looks up, sees a MAN standing before him. His neckti and demeanor suggest manager.
This is the best burger I ever had.  13.
We aim to please. The man smiles, extends a friendly hand.
Mac McDonald.
Ray Kroc. They shake. Kroc pulls a BUSINESS CARD from a pocket, han it to him. McDonald looks at it, unsure what to make of i
RAY KROC (CONT’D) The Multimixer fella.
(it clicks in--) You spoke to my brother. Mac looks again at the card, noting the Chicago address.
What brings you way out here?
Oh, I was just in Los Angeles. Meetings. Business. Figured as long as I was in the neighborhood, I'd swing by, say hello.
Well, I’m glad you did. Welcome! Kroc’s eyes drift to the busy, humming restaurant.
Quite an operation you got here.
Care for a little tour? There’s nothing Kroc would like more.
A bustling kitchen, organized as a series of stations.  14.
Speed... ON MAC-- leading Kroc through the kitchen.
That’s the name of the game. They come to a massive GRILL manned by THREE COOKS.

First stop for every McDonald's hamburger is the grill, manned by three cooks whose sole job is to grill those all-beef beauties to perfection. Kroc watches the mouth-watering beef sizzling on the gril
Meanwhile... He leads Kroc to an adjacent station, where two DRESSERS stand before a rotating Lazy Susan with 24 BUN TOPS on it
As the patty cooks, our “dressers” get the bun ready. DRESSER #1 puts pickle slices and onion on each bun--
Every McDonald’s hamburger gets two pickles, a pinch of onion... --while DRESSER #2 applies a squirt of ketchup and mustar with a pair of trigger-operated CONDIMENT GUNS.
..-and a precise shot of ketchup and mustard.
(re: condiment guns) Where'd you get those things?
We made ‘em.
Made them?
Custom built. Whole kitchen is.  15. ON KROC-- utterly amazed.
(resuming tour) Next it’s off to the finishing station... ANGLE ON the Lazy Susan, carrying 24 fully dressed bun to traveling along a belt toward a FINISHING STATION.
Where it all comes together. A pair of FINISHERS put cooked patties onto the fully dre bun tops, then put on bun bottoms and neatly wrap it up.
Voila! The finished product is fed into an angled metal sleeve t slides them to the front counter, where cashiers can grab bag them with ease.
A fresh and delicious hamburger, grill to counter in 30 seconds. ON KROC-- dumbfounded by what he’s seen. He looks at Mac.
How?
Did I come up with all of this? (sly smile) I didn’t. Kroc is confused.
We did. Kroc follows Mac’s eyes to a MAN coming toward them.
Dick McDonald. My brother. Kroc grabs Dick’s hand, enthusiastically shakes.
I just have to say, what you’ve done here is nothing short of--  16.
(to Mac, ignoring Ray) The fries.
What about ‘em? Dick leads Mac toward the FRENCH FRY STATION. Kroc follow along. Dick plucks a fry off the drying rack, hands it to Mac, who pops it in his mouth.
Perfect.
They're five percent too crisp. Dick takes a fry, tastes it. Frowns. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) I think we should drop to two minutes, 50 seconds.
That's what you had it at before.
400, not 375. Higher temp, shorter cook. Mac takes another taste.
I really think they’re spot-on.

(to Dick) If it makes any difference, they're the best fries I’ve ever tasted. Crispy golden brown on the outside, fluffy on the inside. Not too oily, perfectly salty and crunchy. Dick looks at Ray, taking note of him for the first time.
Who are you?
This is that Multimixer fella you spoke to.
Ray Kroc, Prince Castle Sales.  17. Kroc hands Dick his card. Dick gives it a cursory glance.
How soon you figure we can expect ‘em?
I’m sending them Blue Label Air. You should have it early next week.
Good. With this, Dick abruptly walks off. Ray gives chase.
Wait! He catches up, grabs Dick’s arm. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Let me take you out to dinner.
(jokey) You're really not my type.
You and your brother. Mac, a few feet away, comes over, curious.
What for?

I’m gonna shoot straight with you fellas. This restaurant is the most remarkable thing I’ve seen in all my years in the food-service industry. And believe you me, I've seen it all. I want to know everything about it. Where it came from, how you thought of it. (BEAT)
Please. Tell me your story.
Kroc sits across from the brothers in a corner booth, rib steaks in front of all three.  18.
There wasn’t a job in all of Manchester. All of New Hampshire. So we packed our bags and headed west. To Hollywood. I wanted to be in the movie business. And Dick, well, he wanted to be...
Employed.

We landed jobs driving trucks for Columbia Pictures. After a few years, we had enough saved up to buy our own little piece of show business. A little movie theater out in Glendora. Which would've been swell, except for the small matter of timing. It was September of ‘29. One minute we’re screening “Gold Diggers Of Broadway”, the next it’s “Brother, can you spare a dime?” Literally.
I couldn't.

Nobody in town was making any money. Except this one fella, Wylie Reid. Ran a hot dog and root beer stand. People still gotta eat, right? So we decide to set up our own stand, hot dogs and orange juice, out in Arcadia.
A YOUNG DICK AND MAC manning their dusty, roadside HOT DO STAND during the Great Depression. A smattering of CUSTOM
It did okay, enough to keep us off the bread line, but we were hardly doing gangbusters. There just weren’t enough people in Arcadia.  19.

Meanwhile, one town over is San Bernardino, the place is growing at a terrific clip. We want to relocate, but we’ve got no money for a new stand. That’s when my brother here gets one of his brilliant ideas. Tell him, Dick. Dick throws Mac a “That’s okay, you tell him” nod.
“Why don’t we move the stand we’ve got? Put it on a truck!” (BEAT)

Genius, right? Except one small problem. On the road between the towns, there’s an overpass. The building doesn’t clear. I figure that’s it, we’re done for. But then Dick says... Another nod of deferral from Dick.
“Why don’t we saw the restaurant in half?”
Dick and Mac driving an old flatbed Ford. On the back is stand, SPLIT IN TWO. The truck goes under an overpass, narrowly clearing.
We truck the darn thing over in two pieces, put it back together!
Kroc guffaws with amazement.

We move the building, set up shop. But before we open, we decide to give the place a little tweak. It’s 1940. Drive-ins are all the rage, the hottest thing going. I say Dick, we gotta get in on this. Dick says sure. (MORE )
Two months later, we open for business... (show-biz hands) “McDonald’s Famous Barbecue!”
The brothers’ proto-McDonald’s, up and running. Pretty CARHOPS in tasseled short skirts and Western boots hustle about serving customers.

We've got a 27-item menu, barbecue slow-cooked in a real pit out back. Uniformed waitresses bring the food straight out to your car. It does gangbusters. Going great guns. But then, sales start to level off.

The drive-in model, as we learn, has a few built-in problems. Kroc leans in, eager to hear their take on this. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) For starters, there’s the customer issue. Drive-ins tend to attract, shall we say, a less-than desirable clientele.
Teenagers.

Hot rodders and hooligans. Juvenile delinquents in blue jeans. Kroc nods, all too familiar. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) Then there’s the service. It takes forever and a day for your food to arrive. And when it finally does--
It’s completely wrong.  Kroc nods. 21.
The carhops are too busy dodging gropes to remember you wanted a strawberry phosphate, not cherry.
If they remember at all.
Then there’s the expenses. Payroll is high due to the large staff required. Dishes are constantly getting stolen or broken.
Tremendous overhead.
But one day Dick has a realization. Going over the books, he notices something. The bulk of our sales come from just three items: Burgers, fries, soft drinks.
87 percent.
We say to ourselves, what the heck are we doing monkeying around with all this other stuff? Focus on what sells. Yes.
And that’s just what we do. Brisket, gone. Tamales, gone. And we don’t stop at the menu. We look at everything. What else don’t we need?
Turns out, quite a lot.
Carhops.
Walk up to a window. Get your food yourself.
Dishes.  22.
All paper packaging. Disposable.
Jukeboxes, cigarette machines.
Drive out the riff-raff.
(totally in sync) Create a family-friendly environment!
And finally, the biggest, most important cut of all... the wait.
Orders ready in 30 seconds, not 30 minutes.
We decide to tear down the kitchen. Rebuild. Reconfigure. Rethink the whole dang thing. And you're gonna love how we do it. Tell him, Dick.
The tennis court?
He brings me out to this tennis court, draws an outline in the dirt. Exact dimensions of our kitchen.
A TENNIS COURT, somewhere in San Bernardino. Mac watches Dick carefully draws a KITCHEN OUTLINE on it with a stick
We bring in a bunch of employees, have ‘em go through the motions, making pretend burgers and fries. --An invisible kitchen, YOUNG EMPLOYEES mimicking the mov trying to get it right.  23.

Dick’s chasing after them with the stick, marking up where all the equipment should go. They do it over and over, hashing out the moves, choreographing like it’s some sort of crazy burger ballet. --Over and over. It’s starting to get dark.
Finally, after about six hours of this, we get it just right. --Workers making pretend burgers and fries in perfect syn
A symphony of efficiency. Not a wasted motion.
We take the layout to a builder, custom build to exact specs.
Ta-da. The Speedee System is born. The world’s first-ever system designed to deliver food fast. It's totally revolutionary.
And a complete disaster.
The grand opening. The hungry and the curious pulling up.

Opening day, people pull into the lot, immediately start honking when no carhop comes over. We try to explain the walk-up window. They're bewildered. Furious. “Whaddaya mean I gotta get out of my car?”  24.
Most of them just cuss us out and drive off. The few that stick around are mad as heck about having to eat off paper and discard their own trash.
We may have underestimated the learning curve.

By five o'clock, Dick’s calculating the cost of converting back to drive-in. But me, I’m not quite ready to throw in the towel. Going back to my Hollywood roots, I say to myself, “We gotta go big with this. We gotta put on a show.” I tell Dick I want to throw a grand re-opening. A gala premiere to put Louis B. Mayer to shame.
The fast-food equivalent of a Hollywood-style premiere.

We rent a bunch of spotlights, the same ones we used to truck around to premieres in the Columbia days. I get sparklers, a juggler for the kiddies--it’s an event. People show up in droves. And then...
The flies. --An ominous cloud gathers over the restaurant. A SWARM O INSECTS. They swoop down in unison, as if in attack mode.
They must've been drawn by all the lights.
Millions of ‘em. Looked like something out of Exodus. --Customers running, screaming. Swatting.  25.
The Pharaoh would’ve released the Israelites.
It’s a total disaster. Towel time. (BEAT)

The next morning, Dick and I meet up to discuss going back to the old format. As we're talking, there’s a knock at the service window. Dick goes over, sees a little boy standing there. He wants a bag of burgers.
Dick at the service window, looking at a YOUNG KID. His n barely clears the counter.
I tell him we're closed.
But he’s cute, I feel bad for him, so I fire up the grill, make hima batch. And as he’s heading off... --A car pulls into the lot.
A car pulls up. --A second car.
Then another. --A third car.
And another. Before you know it, there’s a line around the block. --A LINE OF CUSTOMERS stretching into the distance.
Word has spread.  26.
And it’s off to the races.
We’re an overnight sensation. Thirty years in the making. ON KROC-- absorbing all of this, blown away. Mac gives Kroc a modest little shrug.
So that’s our story.
Kroc lies awake in bed, buzzing, unable to sleep.
Dick and Mac pull into the McDonald’s lot in Dick’s car. They’re startled to see-- Kroc, sitting out front. He approaches their car. Before can fully roll down his window:
Franchise.
Beg pardon?

Franchise, franchise the thing. It’s too good to just be one location. There ought to be McDonald's everywhere. Coast to coast, sea to shining sea. And I’m just the man to help you do it. I’ve spent the better part of my life criss-crossing this country. I know every highway and byway, every city and every town.
Mr. Kroc...
Let me just say one thing. One more thing. (MORE)

I want to confess something to you boys. I’m not out here in California on any business meeting. I’m out here for you. You’re what brought me out. A few days ago, I was standing outside a filling station in St. Louis, Missouri staring at a U.S. road map, staring at a long, white, unbroken line called Route 66. I took my finger--
Mr. Kroc-—

I took my finger, and I traced that line from where I was standing all the way out to California, where it ran smack-dab into this place we are now. As I stared at that line, something told me to follow it. Something told me to get in my car and see what’s out there at the other end. And when I laid eyes on your hamburger stand yesterday, all those people lined up to purchase your remarkable product, I knew it was-—-
We already tried!
Kroc and the brothers stand before a U.S. MAP.
Five. ANGLE ON map. Five PUSH PINS are stuck in it, clustered around California and the Southwest. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) Three in Southern California, one in Sacramento and one in Phoenix. (BEAT)
And that’s all there’1ll ever be.
Why?  28.
Two words: Quality control. It’s almost impossible to enforce standards from afar.
Those places were a mess. Filthy kitchens, inconsistent menus...
Sacramento was selling burritos.
To watch your precious creation get mismanaged like that. Your name.
Put Mac in the hospital. Kroc looks at Mac, surprised. A BEAT as
Diabetes and extreme stress don’t mix. Kroc absorbs this.
But if you had somebody in charge of supervising.
We did.
What happened?
He obviously didn’t do a great job.
So replace him. With someone better.
Our energies are better spent making this place the best it can possibly be.
Better one great restaurant than 50 mediocre ones.  29.
Sure, but I still think if you had the right--
Thank you, we’re not interested.
Someone as committed to quality as--
Thank you. Kroc backs off. A BEAT of awkward silence. Kroc’s eye goes to something else on the wall... a BLUEPR The building has towering arches on each side.
What’s that?
A blueprint.
Those: Mac follows Kroc’s eyes to the arches.
It’s a way to make the place stand out when you’re driving past.
“The Golden Arches” I call ‘em. Kroc stares at them, fascinated. It’s a crazy, radical (a kind of brilliant) thing to stick on the sides of a build
Who thought of that?
That’s pure Dick magic right there. Dick’s gaze is still on the arches, clearly proud.
Ever do one like that?

Just one...  30. Dick looks at the U.S. map. A lonely push pin in the midd of Arizona. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) Phoenix. EXT. ROUTE 66 - SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA/ARIZONA -— DAY Kroc driving back along Route 66, taking in the scenery. SERIES OF SHOTS: Kroc passing through various small towns each with a Main Street running through it. On every Main Street, we see the same two things: a church and courthou Glimpses of various churches and courthouses. Churches to with crosses. Courthouses with American flags. ON KROC-- processing, wheels turning.
Kroc driving through Flagstaff. He passes a road sign: I-
He takes an impulsive detour.

Kroc drives down Phoenix’s Central Avenue. He sees the ar before he sees the restaurant. Kroc pulls into the empty lot (the restaurant is closed). gets out, looks up at the arches. KROC’S HOUSE (DES PLAINES, IL) - DAY A modest home in the Chicago suburbs. Kroc pulls up in hi car.  31.
ETHEL (53) is at the table, eating dinner by herself.
Ethel! Kroc comes bursting in, burning with excitement. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I’ve seen the future! Ethel’s face falls.
Again?
I saw a restaurant, Ethel. It’s like nothing you’ve ever seen. They've got this system, the Speedee System...
Ray...
Just hear me out.
I’m too old for this.
This place, it’s like something sprung from the mind of Henry--
I can’t do it. Not again.
Don’t you want to be a part of greatness?
I want to be part of a cruise. (BEAT)

All our friends are taking trips, enjoying their golden years. And us, we're still scrapping and scraping like a couple of 25-year- olds. When do we get to start living, Ray? When do we finally get to start enjoying our lives?  This sets 32.
Ethel, this place--
It’s revolutionary.
(bristles at her sarcasm) As a matter of fact...
It’s never going to get any better, Ray. We’re never going to have anything more than we have right now. And that’s okay. (BEAT)
What’s not okay is us wasting our lives reaching for some brass ring we're never going to grab.
(flash of anger) Maybe if I had a wife who had an ounce of vision. Who gave me an ounce of support.

Support? Support? her off-- ETHEL KROC (CONT’D) All I’ve done is support you! I’ve had your back through thick and thin, through one cockamamie idea after another. The wax cups, the Fold-A-Nook, the Multi-Mixer, on and on, every last one. And you have the nerve to say I don’t support you?
(backing off, chastened) I’m sorry.
I’ve believed in you, Ray. Our whole marriage. Long past the point any rational, thinking person would've.
You're right.  33.
I’ve sacrificed, I’ve saved. Made do, gone without. My belt’s so tight, I’m out of notches.
You're right.
“Support”? (BEAT )
How dare you? Kroc just stands there in shamed little-boy silence.
Kroc steps to the ticket window.
One ticket, please. The marquees reads MAGNIFICENT OBSESSION.

Kroc sits in the theater, the light of the screen flicker off his face. In his hand is his flask. He takes a discre swig. INT. PRINCE CASTLE SALES - KROC’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS June Martino watches Kroc pace, ringing phone to his ear.
McDonald’s Hamburgers.

Mac, then. The employee puts the phone down, goes off to check. Thro it, Kroc hears what sounds like a BIG CROWD.  34.

10 o'clock.

One ticket to Los Angeles.
The dinner rush. Mac and Dick hustle about making sure th run as smoothly as possible. ON DICK-- reloading the Lazy Susan with bun tops.  35.
Do it for your country.
(turns, surprised) Ray.
What are you doing here? Mac is there, too.
If you boys don’t want to franchise for yourselves, fine. But do it for your country. For America. (BEAT)
This place you’ve created, it’s not a restaurant. It’s not even a place. It’s an idea. ON DICK-- absorbing.
(to nearby employee) Tommy, finish the buns.
Kroc stands before the brothers.

That drive back home on 66, I passed through a lot of towns. A lot of small towns. In the middle of each one of them was a Main Street. And on each of those Main Streets were always the same two things: a courthouse and a church. A courthouse topped with a flag. A church topped with a cross. Flags and crosses, crosses and flags. The brothers look at each other, unsure where this is goi RAY KROC (CONT’D) As I drove along, I pondered those crosses and flags. I asked myself why they’re so ubiquitous. What they mean. And as I did, I couldn’t help but think about your restaurant. About these--  36. He goes over to the blueprint, plants a finger on the arc RAY KROC (CONT’D) Now, forgive me if this flirts with blasphemy, but to my mind, these arches share a great deal in common with the Christian cross and the American flag. A building topped with a cross is a gathering place. A place where decent, wholesome folks can come together and be with others who share their values. The same can be said of a building flanked by a pair of your arches. Those arches mean more than simply “delicious hamburgers inside”. They signify family. Community. The ties that bind. They represent goodness, togetherness, a place for Americans to gather and break bread. McDonald’s can be that, too. The new American church, feeding bodies and feeding souls. And not just on Sundays. Seven days a week. (BEAT)
Crosses. Flags. Arches. ON MAC-- blown away. He looks over at Dick, expecting a similar reaction. He’s surprised to see a conflicted look his face.
(to Kroc) Would you please give us a minute?
The brothers, alone in the office.
(tempted, torn) I don’t know...
It’s your dream, Dick. (eye contact) Bigger than your dream. Arches-- your arches--coast to coast. Dick’s eyes go to the U.S. map. A whole country, just wai to be filled in with push pins.  37.
I can’t put you through that again. ON MAC-- looking at Dick gazing longingly at the map.
I know how bad you want this. You should have it.
Last time, you very nearly wound up—
We'll do it different this time. Learn from our mistakes.
How so?
We keep a much tighter leash. Total oversight, every change has to go through us.
Who says he’s gonna listen?
We draw up a contract. Lay it out, clear as day in black and white. ON DICK-- pondering. Seemingly warming to the idea.
Whaddaya say?
Ray Kroc sits across a table from the brothers and their LAWYER. Kroc is skimming through a BIG FAT CONTRACT. Full clauses and sections and paragraphs. ANGLE ON contract. Amidst a wall of legalese:

And now, we’re poised to make major inroads nationally. The loan officer looks at a set of BLUEPRINTS on his desk titled MCDONALD'S #6 - DES PLAINES, ILL. Something catc his eye.

Artist renderings, projected earnings, etc. ON KROC-- anxiously watching as he leafs through it. RAY KROC (CONT’D) (filling the air) There’s nothing like it in the entire food-service sector. You look familiar. Have we met?
(a drop uneasy) I don’t believe so. ON LOAN OFFICER, staring, determined to place the face. H snaps his fingers--

Have we met? The man searches his face. Kroc squirms. LOAN OFFICER #2 (CONT’D) The paper-cup guy. ON KROC-- silent a long beat.  40.
(embarrassed, broken) Among many other things. The loan officer stares at Kroc, taking in his vulnerable Willy Loman-esque visage. A wave of compassion/pity comes over him.
I tell you what. Let me refer you to one of my colleagues. Somebody who may be better suited to meet your needs.
Kroc sits before a different LOAN OFFICER. The man is fil out an APPLICATION FORM for Kroc.
Address?

Home telephone number?

Let me give you my office number. Kroc glances at his WEDDING RING. RAY KROC (CONT’D) That’s the best place to reach me. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY ANGLE ON blueprints for the Des Plaines McDonald's coveri Kroc’s walls.
Did you schedule the stakeout with the engineer?
All set.  41. ON KROC-- at his desk, plowing through a lengthy to-do li as June takes notes.
Where are we at on fire department approval for driveway design?
Left a message yesterday.
Call again. Excavation permit?
Meeting with them today.
Insurers?
I left a message yesterday.
Call again. What about the zoning office?
All set. On file with the city.
San Bernardino?
I just spoke to Dick. He says they're working on it.
Working on it? He lets out a heaving, irritated sigh. RAY KROC (CONT’D) It’s been a week.
Dick is at his desk. An EMPLOYEE sticks his head in.
Ray Kroc, line one.
Hiya, Ray.  42.
You boys are killing me. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS (Intercut as necessary.)
What’s the hold up? I break ground in two weeks.
These things take time. You're proposing substantial alterations.
I’m adding a basement and furnace.
We need our architect to thoroughly review it to make sure everything's safe and up to code.
Has he looked at it yet?
I’m not sure, to be honest.
I can’t afford to let this drag.
Ray, you need to take a breath. It hasn’t even been a week.
I’ve got bulldozers rolling up on the 23rd.
I’m not the one who scheduled that.
Do you have any idea what it’d cost me to push?
Hopefully, it won’t come to that.
Every restaurant in the Midwest has a basement and a furnace. This is standard stuff.

I understand. But you have to understand, it’s our name on that building. God forbid the floor caves in and people get hurt or worse because of some design flaw we missed, we’re the ones on the hook. So let’s just slow down a minute and make sure it’s done the right way. Alright? pondering Dick’s words of reason.
So much for the Speedee System! He hangs up.
Mac is in the office with Dick.
Then what did he say?
He slammed down the phone.
He hung up on you?
Unless we got violently disconnected. Dick looks off, feeling the first pangs of buyer’s remors
It’ll be fine.

Can we bring that out another foot?
Sir? June comes over to Kroc with a letter. He looks at it, se the San Bernardino return address.
Read it. She opens the letter, reads aloud--

As you rightly point out, such an arrangement would provide a steady source of revenue to the store at no additional labor cost. ON KROC-- pleased with the letter so far. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) “However...

Small, along the bottom. Very discrete.
On the other end is Mac in the kitchen, his brother nearb (Intercut as necessary.)

Not an ad. Sponsorship.  45.
It’s distasteful.
It’s free money.
There are plenty of things we could do to make a quick buck, but that doesn’t mean we should.
Loads of restaurants do it.
Well, we don’t.
Why not?
Because I have no interest in indulging in that sort of crass commercialism. It’s not McDonald's.
I didn’t realize I was partnering up with a beatnik.
I happen to be a card-carrying Republican.
You coulda fooled me! He slams down the phone. Again.
Mac and Dick, post-call.
He’s just a little... excitable.
A hothead like that, you don’t know what he’s capable of.
It’s all bluster, Dick. His bark is worse than his bite.  46.
(dark chuckle) That’s what Neville Chamberlain said.

The brand-new Des Plaines McDonald's, up and running. TRACKING SHOT, high-energy, as Kroc moves through the KIT barking out orders to his charges. Kroc enters, home from another lo day of work. He starts getting undressed. As he unbuttons his shirt, he hears a sound. A tiny sniff Ethel is awake, crying softly. He goes over, sits on the bed next to her.
I’m sorry. ON KROC-- taking in her sad, lonely face. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I know I’ve neglected you. He looks her in the eye. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Tomorrow night. Let’s have supper at the club.
(surprised, heartened) Really?
It’s been far too long. He hands her a tissue. She blows her nose.  48.
The dining room of a not especially upscale country club. Kroc leads Ethel to a big round table. At it are fellow C MEMBERS, who warmly greet them.
By George, I think I’ve seen a ghost!
The middle of the meal. Ray kibitzes with the men, Ethel engaged in a cross-conversation with the wives.
I hear Acapulco is divine.
Mildred Ballard was just there. She adored it. Ethel nods along, not wanting to stick out. CLUB WIFE #2 (CONT’D) Where do you like, Ethel?
Me? (BEAT, scrambling) Spain.
Wonderful! How was it?
(backtracks ) I mean, we're thinking about it. Planning to, in the fall. Nods and smiles from the other women. The conversation mo on, bullet dodged.

text: That's the last time I try a sand wedge in that bunker! Hearty laughs from the others, loving the golf humor.
How's your game, Ray?
Lately? Non-existent. The men laugh, missing the literalness of the statement.
I’m no Ben Hogan myself. ON KROC-- seeing an opening in the conversation.

(cryptic smile) But I did recently hit a hole-in- one of a different sort. The men glance at each other, intrigued. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Anyone interested in hearing about an exciting investment opportunity? Kroc sneaks a glance at Ethel. She’s staring at him, crestfallen. So this is why we’re at the club.
(chuckle) Here we go again... ON HORFORD-- smiling at Kroc, a bit condescendingly. JACK HORFORD (CONT’D) What is it this time, Ray? ON ETHEL-- taking in the way Horford looks at her husband irks her.

Hear him out. Ethel looks at Ray, looks back at Horford. ETHEL KROC (CONT’D) This is different. ON KROC-- surprised and touched she has his back. He grab her hand under the table, looks her reassuringly in the e Yes, it is. It is different this time.  50.

Kroc pulls into the parking lot of Jack Horford’s brand-n Schaumburg McDonald's. There’s a line out front, not spectacular but solid. He parks, heads toward the restaurant. He slows, noticing something. KROC’S POV: A patron in his car, biting into a hamburger. Sticking out the sides of the burger is a PIECE OF LETTUC ON KROC-- staring at the lettuce, disturbed by the sight.
Jack Horford, part of a foursome, is about to tee off.

Give it a whack, Jack. Horford rears back to swing when, out the corner of his e he sees-- KROC, storming onto the course, marching toward him. As Kroc gets closer, Horford sees he’s holding something. a HAMBURGER. Kroc gets right up in his face with it.
What is this? Horford stares at the burger.  51.
It appears to be a hamburger.
It’s not a McDonald’s hamburger. He lifts off the bun, pointing out its myriad deficiencie RAY KROC (CONT’D) Too much ketchup. Three pickles not two. Lettuce. Lettuce, Jack?
Do you think we could discuss this later? We’re in the middle of--
And the patty. (breaks it open) Tragically overcooked.
I don’t know, Ray... Fellow franchise owner Jerry Cullen (part of the foursome leans in, checking out the burger. JERRY CULLEN (CONT’D) Looks good to me.
(glares at Cullen) What the heck would you know about quality? ON CULLEN-- thrown. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I dropped in on your store today. I must say, I was quite disturbed.
What by?
For starters, the menu... Corn on the cob?
What’s wrong with corn on the cob?
Fried chicken?  52.
People love fried chicken.
Then they can go to a restaurant that serves it! Cullen and Horford trade glances, bewildered. RAY KROC (CONT’D) And the filth. The kitchen looked like some sort of Manchurian slum.
(smirk) With great chicken. Everybody laughs. Kroc is not amused.
(to both of them) Are you aware of what goes on at your restaurants? Do you even care?
Look, Ray, I don’t know about you, but I’m retired.
You said this’d be a good place to park our money. It’s an investment, nothing more.
If I wanted a job, I'da applied for a cook position. ON KROC-- silently stewing. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Ethel is getting dressed, putting on jewelry and makeup. enters, home from work.
Hurry up and get changed. Dinner’s called for seven.
We’re not going to the club tonight.  53.
You cancelled our dinner plans?
I cancelled our membership.
What?
Those Rolling Green people aren’t our kind.
What are you talking about?
I’ve lost interest in hobnobbing with the idle rich.
Idle rich?
With their golf and their Rob Roys.
Please tell me this is a joke.
Contented. Complacent.
Those are my friends, Ray. My entire social life!
We'll find new friends. Ethel throws herself onto the bed, bursting into tears. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Far more suitable.
Kroc sits in his car across the street from Jack Horford’ McDonald's, anonymously watching-- KROC’S POV: A crowd of ANNOYED CUSTOMERS waiting for thei food. A customer checks his watch.  54.

(to cashier) How much longer? Kroc watches the shabbily run operation, sickened. He tak swig from his flask. The pre-lap sound of VOMITING carries over to-- INT. Just take a gander at this handsome gold inlay. Kroc comes to the desk, where he sees a BIBLE SALESMAN (2 talking to June, briefcase full of samples popped open.
You're telling me such spectacular craftsmanship isn’t worth $8.95?
Thank you, I’m not interested.
Not interested in a Bible sure to be the pride of your home library? ON KROC-- observing the young salesman.
As you no doubt know, June, envy is one of the seven deadly sins. And that’s just what your friends and neighbors will be guilty of when they see this leather-bound beauty on your bookshelf.

Sir, this is a private place of business. I’m afraid I’m going to have to ask you to leave.  55. BEAT. The salesman gathers up his things, heads out of th office. June’s telephone rings. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) Prince Castle Sales. (BEAT, listening) Oh, hello, Mac. Kroc hears the name. A knot instantly forms in his stomac JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) One moment, I’1l see if he’s in. The salesman heading down the hall toward the elevator.

Leonard. Leonard Rosenblatt.
Rosenblatt. ON KROC-- digesting the name, intrigued. RAY KROC (CONT’D) What’s a Jew doing selling Catholic Bibles?

(unapologetic) Making a living. ON KROC-- taking in the hungry young go-getter. It’s not to read his mind. This is just the sort of fella I need.  56. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Rosenblatt and his wife MYRA (22) sit across from Kroc. K slides a pen and contract to them. ON LEONARD AND MYRA ROSENBLATT-- looking at each other. Excited, hopeful. A young couple, staking everything on a shared dream. Myra gives his hand a squeeze.
I believe in you.

Us, Myra. ON KROC-- watching the interaction with admiration--and a touch of jealousy. EXT. MCDONALD'S (THE ROSENBLATTS’) - DAY (A FEW MONTHS LA The Rosenblatts’ new McDonald's in Waukegan, IL. The hustle and bustle of a smooth-running kitchen. It’s a model of cleanliness and professionalism, everything the country clubbers’ locations were not. ON KROC-- in the middle of it all, observing, highly plea
Let’s go, chop-chop! ON ROSENBLATT-- moving around the kitchen, barking out orders, making sure everything’s just so.

Here y’go, champ! Kroc looks toward the front of the store, where he sees.. Myra, handing out lollipops to children. She’s wearing a apron that says MCDONALD’S--and a big smile on her face. You've never seen a pair of dynamos like these two. ON ETHEL-- in bed, half-listening, about to fall asleep. RAY KROC (CONT’D) He’s in back, running the kitchen, she’s up front, passing out suckers to the kiddies. Like a real team. (BEAT)
It’s wonderful. Don’t you think? No reply from the sleepy Ethel. He gives her a poke. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Don't you?
Don’t I what?
Think it’s wonderful. (angling) Two people, side by side, working together...
Are you trying to hire me, Ray?
You say you never see me anymore. This is a perfect way.
I don’t want to work for you.
With me. Husband and wife, united in labor and in life. You know?
I mean...  58. ON ETHEL-- pondering, really struggling with the notion. ETHEL KROC (CONT’D) Not really. A stretch of tense, edgy silence.
I made us supper plans for Friday.

No. (gazes off) Someplace far better.

PAN DOWN to a long table lined with couples. Blue-collar types, several rungs down the social ladder from Rolling Green. And younger, average age closer to 30 than 60. In the midst of them, we find Ray and Ethel. They’re dres deliberately “blue collar”, matching the people around th ON ETHEL-- edgily pushing her meatloaf and mashed potatoe around her plate.

Well, I had a little plumbing business going for a while after getting out of the service. Now I sell vacuum cleaners. And give piano lessons on the side.
Golly. Plumbing, pianos, you're a regular jack of all trades.
Whatever puts food on the table.  59. Art’s WIFE smiles proudly at her hard-working man. ON KROC-- sizing them up. They fit the profile to a T.
How would you like to do more than merely “put food on the table”?
INT. KROC’S OFFICE - SHORT TIME LATER Art Wolodarsky signing up for a franchise, his faithful w by his side. This leads to--
Kroc hunting for new recruits for the McDonald's Army. Qu cuts of Kroc making the SAME SPEECH in various places. Shriners halls, synagogues, Amway meetings:
I’m looking for a few good men! Hustlers! Scrappers! Grinders! Men willing to roll up their sleeves, men with fire in their bellies! (BEAT)

I stand before you today offering something more precious than gold: opportunity. Opportunity to advance. To succeed. To get your shot at the brass ring, the American Dream. For McDonald's, like this great nation itself, is a true meritocracy. If you’re willing to put in the work, if you’ve got the gumption and the guts and the desire, the sky’s the limit at McDonald's. Put in the necessary elbow grease and, by gum, I promise you there’s a pot of gold waiting for you at the end of those Golden Arches. So who’s with me? Who's ready to strap it on and step onto that first rung of the ladder of success? Who’s ready to make that glorious upward climb, ascending into the hard-won heavens of success and prosperity? We finally de the first stirrings of jealousy. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Speaking of Inst-A-Mix, have you seen the new issue of “RBM”?  93. Kroc reaches inside his coat, pulls out a copy of “Restau Business Monthly”. Hands it to Rollie. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Hot off the press. ON ROLLIE-- taking in the cover... ANGLE ON magazine. Kroc is the cover boy. A big photo of in his office, smiling, holding the hamburger. The headli MCDONALD’S TAKES A BITE OUT OF THE COMPETITION - UPSTART HAMBURGER EMPORIUM IS ‘ON THE GROW’ ON JOAN-- looking at Ray on the cover. Looking at Ray in flesh. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Ethel is asleep in bed, alone.
Kroc is on the phone, speaking quietly.
(intrigued) Bloomington... INT. ROLLIE AND JOAN SMITH’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Joan is on the kitchen phone, also speaking softly. She’s wearing a nightie.
It’s about 10 miles south of downtown. They’re building a brand- new sports stadium there.
I read about that.
We're getting a professional baseball and football team. They’11l both be playing there.
I think I see where you’re going with this...
A 40,000-seat stadium, just a stone’s throw away. Imagine the foot traffic.
Hungry families looking for a bite after the ballgame.
Or before. Whenever.
I like the way you think, Joan. You think big.
Is there any other way to?
You'd be surprised. His gaze drifts downward. To his wedding ring. RAY KROC (CONT’D) A lot of people, they’re scared. Of taking a chance. Reaching for greatness.
That’s so sad.
I agree. Ambition, that’s the stuff of life.
What’s that saying? “Fortune favors the bold.”
Absolutely.
Just look at you.
Are you calling me bold, Joan?
You don’t build a restaurant empire acting like a timid little mouse.  95.
Kroc lies in bed next to Ethel. His hands drift downward under the covers, toward his nether regions. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc, Harry Sonneborn and Fred Turner stand huddled over map of Texas.
(re: some city on map) That's a fast-growing area. The phone rings outside the room. HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) And cheaper. You’re talking a good 15 percent less per acre.
I still say Houston’s the move.
Sir? June Martino is standing in the doorway. JUNE MARTINO (CONT’D) Dick on line one.
Dick on the phone in his office, Mac in the background.
I just got a very disconcerting call. Kroc on the other end--Harry, Fred and June listening in. Kroc has a smug, cocky air, “playing to the crowd” a bit.
Oh?
From Buddy Jepsen. Our operator in Sacramento.
I’m well aware who Buddy Jepsen is.  96.
He told me he received a shipment this morning.
It arrived?
You are way out of line, Ray.
I figured it wouldn’t get there until Friday the earliest.
Would you mind telling me what you're doing shipping four cases of Inst-A-Mix to one of our operators?
If you’re not interested in turning a profit, that’s fine. But please don’t stop the rest of us.
Us?
Us. As in everyone but you.
Who did you send them to?
Everyone but you.
You have no right, Ray. You are to stop this instant. Is that clear?
Nah.
Excuse me?
You heard me. Nah.
What the hell’s that mean?  97.
It means from now on I’1l be doing things my way.
You will abide by the terms of your deal.
I’m through taking marching orders from you. Bowing to your dictates. You and your endless parade of nos.
You have a contract.
Don’t grow, don’t change... Cower in the face of progress...
If phony powdered milkshakes is your idea of progress, you have a profound misunderstanding of what McDonald’s is about.
I have a far better understanding of McDonald’s than you two yokels.
What did you say?
You heard me.
You will do as we say.
Nope.
You have a contract.

Contracts are like hearts. They’re made to be broken. INT. KROC’S HOUSE - DINING ROOM - NIGHT Kroc and Ethel eat dinner together in edgy silence. All w hear is the sound of knife scraping plate as meat is cut.  98.
Please pass the salt. (he passes it) Thank you.
You’re welcome. Another stretch of silence. Cutting and chewing. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I want a divorce.
The big, oak-paneled office of a top Chicago law firm. Kr sits across from a LAWYER.
It’s not so simple. He looks down at a document in his hand, Kroc’s contract the brothers.
This contract, it’s ironclad.
I don’t care what it takes.
INT. ANOTHER LAWYER’S OFFICE - DAY Virtually the identical scene, except a different office different LAWYER.
Just get me out.
She’s gonna put up one hell of a fight.
She can have it all. The house, the car, the insurance policy...
(treading lightly) What about the...  99.
Never. I'd sooner die than give that woman one share of McDonald’s.

Dick enters the office. He notices a package on his desk, addressed to him and Mac. He opens it, pulls out a silver foil Inst-A-Mix packet. It’s stamped “8S”. Dick reaches in, pulls out a handwritten note from Kroc: NEW FLAVOR... STRAWBERRY. MAYBE YOU’LL LIKE THIS ONE!

His dismay is soon eclipsed by something else: The note from Kroc; it’s not on Franchise Realty Corporat letterhead. The letterhead says THE MCDONALD'S CORPORATIO It’s signed at the bottom RAYMOND A. KROC - PRESIDENT.
Workmen are taking down the Franchise Realty Corporation at the front desk, a new one going up in its place: THE MCDONALD’S CORPORATION.
It was confusing. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Kroc on the phone.
No one knew it had anything to do with McDonald's.
Dick on the other end. Mac there, too.

What’s confusing is you calling yourself the McDonald's Corporation. ON MAC-- listening, strangely calm.  100. DICK MCDONALD (CONT’D) People will think it’s the whole company, not just the real-estate arm. Which I strongly suspect is what you hope. Without warning, Mac SNATCHES THE PHONE out of Dick’s han
IT’S NOT YOUR COMPANY, RAY!
Mac.
Do you understand that?
Don’t get all bent out of shape.

We came up with the Speedee System, not you. Us. What did you ever come up with, Ray? Name one thing. You can’t. Because you never have and you never will. You’re a leech! You're a professional leech! ON DICK-- stunned by his brother’s outburst.

Would you like to know what I came up with? I’1l tell you, Mac. I came up with a concept. A highly novel concept called winning. You boys are content to sit back and be a couple of also-rans. To let the future run roughshod over you. Me, I want to take the future. I want to win. And you don’t get there by being some aw-shucks, nice-guy sap. There’s no place in business for people like that. Business is war. It’s rat eat rat, dog eat dog. If my competitor was drowning, I'd reach out and stick a goddamn hose in his mouth. Can you say the same?
I can’t, nor would I want to.
Hence your single location.  101.
I want you out of this company.
And how do you propose to do that?
Whatever it takes. We’ll sue you if necessary.

You couldn't afford to sue me. I could bury you in court costs alone. I’m the president and CEO of a major corporation with landholdings in 17 states. You run a burger stand in the desert. (blistering, nuclear) I’m national. You’re fucking local. Kroc hears a loud THUD through the phone. Mac has COLLAPSED to the floor. The wail of an AMBULANCE SIREN carries us to--
Mac lies in a hospital bed looking pale and weak. Dick st by as DR. REEVES talks to Mac.

You've been following your eating plan? (Mac nods) Checking your glucose levels? (Mac nods) Taking your medication on a consistent basis? (Mac nods) Regular walks, 20 minutes a day? (Mac nods) No smoking? (Mac nods) Any stress?
(BEAT, understatement of century) Some.  102.
You need to watch that. It’s a big contributing factor. The doctor flips to a page in Mac’s chart.
As I said, your kidney function's currently at 50 percent. 18 months ago, it was 65. Any lower, you’re at serious risk for kidney failure.
Mac is doing a crossword puzzle, Dick in a chair nearby. Mac Mac

How ya feelin’? brothers glare at their unexpected, unwelcome guest. RAY KROC (CONT’D) That was some spill. Felt it all the way through the phone. Kroc extends the flowers to Mac. RAY KROC (CONT’D) For you.  103. Mac takes the flowers like they’re potentially laced with anthrax. He glances at the card attached. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Open it.
That’s alright.
Please. I think you’1l like it. Mac reaches in the envelope, pulls out a GET-WELL CARD. H opens the card. A CHECK falls out. Blank.
What’s this?
What’s it look like?
It looks like a blank check.
Then that’s probably what it is. Mac and Dick look at each other. RAY KROC (CONT’D) How much should I make it out for?
What are you buying? Kroc flashes them a “You don’t know?” smirk.
Mac and Dick both gazing off gloomily. After a long stret of silence--
We'll never beat him. (BEAT)
We'll never be rid of him. ON DICK-- absorbing. He knows Mac is right.  104. INT. KROC’S OFFICE - DAY Kroc is standing before the franchise map. There are near 50 PINS in it now. The intercom buzzes.
Dick McDonald. Kroc picks up, friendly and casual.
Hiya, Dick. On the other end is Dick, in the KITCHEN in San Bernardin
$2.7 million. (BEAT)

It’s outrageous! Borderline extortion! Sonneborn is holding a document. A PURCHASE PROPOSAL from brothers.
And they want one other thing.
What?
San Bernardino. Kroc is taken aback. HARRY SONNEBORN (CONT’D) To give to their longtime employees. As a gift.  105.
I need San Bernardino. I was counting on its profits to cover the debt on the purchase loan.
I've spoken at length about it with their lawyers. It’s unfortunately non-negotiable. ON KROC-- calmly absorbing.
Kroc and the brothers in a conference room, flanked by th respective teams of LAWYERS.
Our client agrees fully to your conditions of sale. With one exception. Your one percent cut of future corporate earnings will have to be carried out on a handshake basis.

On the insistence of my investor group. Their financing is contingent on leaving it out of the contract. It’s unfortunately a dealbreaker for them. Dick and Mac look at each other, extremely wary. RAY KROC (CONT’D) You have my word you’1ll get your full due royalties. He extends his hand, holding it out to them.

Mac and Dick sit alone in the conference room as their lawyers pack up. (Kroc and his team are gone.) ON MAC-- staring somberly at a check in his hands for $1,350,000. ON DICK-- staring somberly at a check in his hands for $1,350,000.  106. INT. MEN'S ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Kroc is at the urinal in the law office’s men’s room. He flushes, heads to the sink to wash his hands. The rest room door opens. In walks Dick. He freezes at th sight of Kroc. Kroc smiles amiably at him in the mirror.
Hello, Dick. ON DICK-- gazing searchingly at Kroc.
I just have to ask you one thing. Something I’ve never understood.
Alright.
That day we met, when we gave you the tour.
What about it?
We showed you everything. The whole system, all our secrets. We were an open book. (Kroc nods) So why didn’t you just--
Rip you off? Run off and start my own place using your ideas? (Dick nods) Because it would have failed.
How do you know?
Am I the only one who ever got the kitchen tour? I bet you invited loads of people back there. Countless would-be burger barons looking to replicate your success.
How many succeeded?
Lots of people started restaurants.
Bigger than McDonald's? (Dick is silent) Of course not. No one has and no one ever will. Because they all lack that one thing that makes McDonald's special.
Which is...
Even you don’t know!
Enlighten me.

It’s not just the system. It’s the name. Dick doesn’t follow. RAY KROC (CONT’D) That name. That glorious name. McDonald. It’s wide open. Limitless. It could be anything, whatever you want it to be. It sounds like... America. (BEAT)

Compare that to, oh, say, Kroc. Now there’s a real lemon. Kroc. What a erock. Load of crock. Crock of shit. Would you eat at a place called Kroc’s? It’s enough to make you lose your appetite, a blunt, Slavic thing like that. But McDonald's, now that’s a name. A fine, handsome, all-American name. That’s a winner’s name, the name of somebody who’s got the world by the tail. A man named McDonald is never going to get pushed around in life.
That’s clearly not the case.

So you don’t have a check for $1.35 million in your pocket? Dick is silenced. RAY KROC (CONT’D) That's the mistake your competitors made. All those would-be imitators. They assumed they could simply take your system, slap on some name like Hamburger Hamlet or Roscoe’s, and presto! Instant success! Not me, I wasn’t so arrogant. I knew there’s no beating a name like McDonald's.
And if you can’t beat ‘em...

Buy ‘em. Dick chuckles in disgust. RAY KROC (CONT’D) I'll never forget the first time I saw that name stretched across the front of your stand. It was love at first sight. From that moment, I knew I just had to have it. And now I do.
You don’t “have” it.
You sure about that? Kroc throws him an unnerving smile.
ANGLE ON the McDonald’s sign in front of the restaurant. PAN DOWN TO... Dick and Mac with Kroc’s lawyers, listenin like they’re being read their Miranda rights.  109.

As per the terms of your agreement, while you are entitled to maintain ownership of this location, you no longer have the right to call it McDonald’s, McDonald or any other such variation so as to create confusion or infringe upon the McDonald’s trademark which is now the exclusive intellectual property of Mr. Raymond A. Kroc.
Workers dismantling the McDonald’s sign. The brothers wat helplessly as their name is removed from their own store.
A new sign going up in its place. With a new name--

Below this, it says, with a whiff of desperation: “WE HAVE BEEN HERE 23 YEARS!” The sign is as close to a McDonald's marquee as is legall possible, but it’s just not McDonald's. It’s heartbreakin PAN ACROSS THE STREET, where we see... A NEW MCDONALD'S under construction. A hard-hatted Kroc i site, watching as the signature Golden Arches go up.

Mr. Kroc? A YOUNG MAN comes over, slightly nervous to approach. YOUNG MAN (CONT’D) My name is Will Davis. I'ma reporter for the Los Angeles Times. I’m interested in doing a profile of you pegged to the opening of your hundredth location here. A BEAT as Kroc thinks it over.

Call my office. They’1l set it up. He reaches into the breast pocket of his sport coat.  110. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Here’s my card. He hands a BUSINESS CARD to the reporter. He looks at it. ANGLE ON card. Beneath a McDonald’s logo, it says, simply
We hold on this for a long BEAT.
Now, I know what you’re thinking...

A lavish, gated MANSION. A BLACK LIMOUSINE pulls into the driveway. INT. MANSION - MASTER BEDROOM —- CONTINUOUS A tuxedo-clad Ray Kroc stands before a mirror, stack of i cards in hand. He’s 68 now; it’s nine years later, 1970.

How the heck does an over-the-hill 52-year-old milkshake-machine salesman build a fast-food empire with 1,600 restaurants in 50 states and five foreign countries, with annual revenues in the neighborhood of $700 million? It’s quite simple: persistence. He turns to the next card. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Nothing in the world can take the place of good old persistence. Talent won't. Nothing’s more common than unsuccessful men with talent. Genius won't. Unrecognized genius is practically a cliché. His words have a familiar ring... They’re lifted straight from “The Power Of The Positive” by Dr. Clarence Floyd Ne (the record from the beginning of the movie), with just a of rephrasing to make it “his own”. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Education won’t. The world is full of educated fools. (MORE )

RAY KROC (CONT’D) Persistence and determination alone are all-powerful. He pauses a beat to let his words of wisdom sink in. RAY KROC (CONT’D) There’s no obstacle under the sun that can’t be overcome with honest hard work and determination. It’s these core principles that enabled me to rise to the top of the heap at a point in life when most men would be thinking about retirement. (glances to side, sly grin) We appear to have that in common, Mr. Governor. He pauses for laughter. RAY KROC (CONT’D) You were, what, 55 when you started in politics? Why, you make me look like a spring chicken! Another pause for laughter. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Look at us, a couple of small-town Illinois boys made good. Only in America... He continues talking to Mr. Governor off to the side-- RAY KROC (CONT’D) By the way, thank you for that splendid introduction. To be named California Chamber of Commerce Man of The Year is thrill enough, but to be presented the award by my dear friend and golf buddy Ronald Reagan, well, that’s just the cherry on the sundae. He turns to the next index card. RAY KROC (CONT’D) Now where was I? Ah, yes, the beginning. The year was 1954. The place, Des Plaines, Illinois. That's where it all started. Right there on Lee Street--  112.
The car’s out front. Joan Smith, now Joan Kroc, comes up behind him.
